Posts.Content: Jun 7, 2009 07:37PM DARLENEDENISE wrote: Lemonpie: Been there with the hand & foot thing with Xeloda and it sounds like you are grade 3 by your description.  Hard to believe, but it can get worse.  Try all of our tips but, get with your onc.  Sounds like you might have to stop for a extra week or two and resume at a lower dose.  Like you I had lobster like hands and feet and couldn't walk or use my hands.  I had to sleep with ice packs on my hands.  I kept trying to tough it out, thinking it would get better, nope, it gets worse.  Soak those puppies in cool water with Epsom salt and elevate them as much as possible.  Take an anti-inflammatory if you can.  Keep your hands straight up in the air with cold compresses.  Do not put your hands and feet in warm or hot water, it really makes them worse.  Everything hurt my feet, even socks.  I found open soft slippers the best when I did need to walk.  It took several days to feel relief.  Slather on the balm several times a day.  You will probably still have the entire bottom of your feet peel off.  My feet also looked dirty until they peeled.  I hope yours isn't as bad as mine was and I hope you feel better asap! I tried to avoid the ER but 911 type diarrhea finally landed me there.  I had to come off for two weeks and then started back at 1/3 dose, much better.  I did that for 3 cycles and have been on 1/2 dose since. I have some minor hand & foot issues at the 1/2 dose.  Even with the stop and start and reduced dose, scans showed my two liver lesions had shrunk more than half after only two months.  Scans again soon and I hope I can continue as I am. By the way, lemon pie is one of my favorite deserts, surely it must be good for cancer! May the force be with you!!!  Darlene

Posts.Content: May 16, 2010 05:31PM DARLENEDENISE wrote: Daisylego:  Glad you are going to scan the noggin.  I have had 11 brain lesions treated with Cyber-knife ranging in size from 2mm to 1cm.   Most of them were 4 & 5 mms.  They do not have to be 1cm to be treated.  Your best options are when they are small in number and size.  I am monitored every 3 months with a brain MRI.  My onc scanned me at diagnosis and then in 3 months and was going to scan at 6 month intervals because of the high likelihood of brain mets for Her2+.  I had no symptoms, but a gut instinct, so I asked for a scan 4 months later.  He said hard to scan again so soon without symptoms and asked if I have ever had a headache and when I replied yes, he said "there's a symptom." He thinks it's crazy to not scan Her2+ patients regularly and does.  He has to wrestle with some insurance companies to get it done at times. We scanned 09/08 and there were 8 lesions all under 5mm.  An unusual headache or dizziness will get you a brain MRI order. I know most of the ladies on this board would jump on a scan if there was even a small chance of having a new site of mets in their bodies, wow,  I just don't understand why they are willing to ignore something that if let go could cause you loose your sight, use of limbs or have seizures.  If the lesion is too large when found, then you can only have a crainiotomy for treatment and cannot use focalized radiation treatment. In some instances there are no choices when it is too large. Of course this is a fearful thing to do, but aren't all of our scans and treatments?  Breast cancer is one of the most common cancers to metastasize to the brain and it is part of the stage IV package.  I wish those that are too scared to pursue monitoring of the brain would keep those thoughts to themselves. A few wrong comments could keep someone from doing the right thing. Ladies facing this aspect of this disease need only support and knowledge.  We have to stay strong and proactive in our treatments!!  Remember 30% of Her2+ will get brain mets, so there is a 70% chance the scan will be CLEAR!!  Even with all of the associated anxiety waiting on the scan, nothing spells relief like a clean scan!!  There is a clinical trial at Rush Universty by a leading neurosurgeon to gather data to try to make routine, regular brain scans standard of care for Her2+ patients.  Daisylego, you are brave, and smart to do this, now go get a clean scan and tell us all about it so we can have a reason to celebrate!!! Love and strength being sent your way...Darlene

Posts.Content: May 23, 2010 07:34AM DARLENEDENISE wrote: It is not new research.  You can google brain mets and Her2 and find many medical studies, ASCO, Peer Review, etc. articles on the subject.  I consult with a doctor at Dana Farber who specializes in bc brain mets and she has written many research papers on the subject. Here is a cut and paste from Brainmetsbc.org web site from FAQ section that puts the info in a clear summation: Breast cancer metastasizes (spreads) to the brain in about 15-20% of women with metastatic disease. However, some factors put patients at higher risk. Women who are under fifty years of age, who have HER2-positive tumors, estrogen receptor-negative tumors, and lung or liver metastases are somewhat more likely to be diagnosed with brain metastases. Studies indicate that mutations in the BRCA1 gene are also a risk factor. Women who have HER2 metastatic disease have a risk of brain metastases ranging from 25-40%.

Posts.Content: Jul 14, 2010 01:36PM DARLENEDENISE wrote: Targeted radiation treatment with spheres can be effective only in limited tumor involvement with location and size of the lesions the determining factor.  It would not be an option with diffuse liver involvement.  High liver enzymes and billirubin are indicative of diffuse involvement where systemic treatment would be needed.  Spheres, ablation and cyberknife are good options when there is limited disease in the right locations and the lesions have not responded fully from chemo.  Stubborn limited mets are the best candidates.  I have consulted on all of these several times and sadly was not able to take advantage of them.  Just a little FYI.  For sure, check out all of your options. Darlene

Posts.Content: Jul 14, 2010 09:51AM DARLENEDENISE wrote: Dantow:  I did indeed survive high liver involvement.  I was initially dx with liver mets from the get go.  They were innumerable and within weeks I was in the hospital with sky high billirubin and alk phos due to blockages.  I was so on the edge, family was called in from out of town.  All the docs would say, is that I was a very sick woman and they didn't know if I would turn around.  Well, here I am!!  I think it is important to get your dear wife on chemo ASAP and to line up a consult at a NCI facility once you get a treatment started.  I get treatment locally in Virginia and go to Dana Farber  for consultive care and access to clinical trials.  I also have had Cyberknife tx at UNC and go there for surveillance and follow up care.  There are many options and I think it is important to have information from thought leaders and researchers in addition to guidance from local oncologists. Data supports rechecking the tumor type when dealing with the liver.  I would want to have discussion with a NCI onc about that possibility.  If she is now Her2 pos or TN, there are specific treatments you would want to use. As you know, everyone responds differently to tx.  Typically, when Xeloda fails, Gemzar is next up.  I had severe side effects on Xeloda and it didn't work well.   I reluctantly moved to Gemzar and I had severe side effects as well and it did not work.   Since Gemzar causes platelet drop and is in the same class of 5FU drugs, perhaps Navelbine might be a consideration (looks like she has many left).  I started it the end of March at a 50% dose and in one cycle my liver enzymes and tumor markers dropped significantly and my liver pain was greatly decreased.  I had to reduce to a 30% dose due to low WBC and RBC.  It is still giving me strong results with minimal side effects even at this modest dose.  I am getting with Herceptin.  I know it can be given with Avastin.  I am not educated about that, but perhaps something to consider for your wife. I will hope for quick results from her tx plan.  Keep us informed and give her a hug from a fellow liver metsister who has been there and is still here!!! Stay strong...Darlene

Take care and my best wishes...Darlene

Posts.Content: Jul 21, 2009 01:19PM DARLENEDENISE wrote: Anne:  I struggled with this decision too.  I had liver mets.  The plan became to remove the primary with the least amount of surgery if my mets responded to chemo.  My onc allowed me to make the surgical decision and then shared that it was his desire to see it removed.  I opted for a lumpectomy since my breast tumor shrank down to almost nothing along with my liver mets.  I told my surgeon if she could get clean margins, not close ones, then we would go with that and add radiation.  If they were close or questionable to go with a mastectomy.  I wanted the primary gone with the least stress on my body and immune system. I wanted to avoid additional reconstructive decisions and potential cosmetic surgeries.  If I have recurrence, then I can have a mastectomy.  The goal for stage IV is not curative, it is to reduce tumor burden and to obtain loco-regional control. I had a conversation with a gal at my onc last year who was stage IV and she said "you don't do surgery on a stage IV patient, it won't help me now and I don't want the risks or the agony of surgery."  I tried to talk with her about the importance of loco-regional control and apparently her breast surgeon did not fully explain what that entailed, so, she had no use for my thoughts. Anyway, the tumor continued to grow, so, she would only do radiation, no surgery.  Well, she endured tremendous pain, infection and many issues with that procedure only to find that she had no choice but to do surgery because the radiation did not work and caused additional problems.  Her surgery was more extensive than it would have been in the beginning because of the radiation damage. I have know several other women who did not have surgery and when their disease progressed, so did the tumor and it broke through the skin and it was horribly painful and smelly and caused additional unnecessary agony during their last months of life. I say, if the window of opportunity opens to do surgery while you are doing relatively well, take advantage and get loco-regional control.  It may or may not add to your survival, but it just might and will help with loco-regional control and to perhaps keep it from invading the chest wall which is very difficult to treat. It's been a year since my successful lumpectomy and I just had my mammogram and the girls are behaving right now.  I hope this gives you and anyone thinking about this issue some thought provoking information.  I might add that you should talk with a BREAST surgeon about this, not a GENERAL surgeon who also does breasts along with other surgeries.  The oncologist's role here is to think about disease management, the breast surgeon will focus on loco-regional control, two different animals that can help support one another. Ask your breast surgeon to show you some pictures of tumors that have progressed out of the breast. Good luck...Darlene

Posts.Content: Sep 15, 2010 09:52PM - edited Sep 15, 2010 09:56PM by DARLENEDENISE FYI:  Dr Damian Dupuy at Rhode Island Hospital is the country's top RFA doctor.  I consulted with him for Nanoknife (still in investigational study) because my lesions were close to portal vein and bile ducts and I was not a candidate for Cryoablation, Cyber (due to volume) or any of the RFA proceedures.  I would go for focalized treatment for a few stubborn liver mets if I was eligible.  Use your chemo options wisely.  They can go fast.  Saddly for me I'm not a candidate for any of these great options.  I was able to send my last CT scans and last three doctor's office notes by mail, used e-mail and the phone for consultation.  It took about 9 days since Dr Dupuy was out part of that week.  There was no cost involved.  I did not use my onc, since he is so busy, it just slows the process.  I just gave him the info for my file once I had an outcome.  And remember, your onc will probably shy away from these treatments, since they know how to treat systemically with chemo and are not always up to date on EVERYTHING out there.  Sometimes we teach them and go after treatment that makes the most sense for us as individuals.  And, of course, everything is not for everybody. Good luck ladies and please let me know how things go. Darlene

Posts.Content: Sep 15, 2010 08:30PM - edited Sep 15, 2010 08:31PM by DARLENEDENISE Rachel:  I have had Cyberknife to the brain and I love what the Cyber has to offer to so many.  My rad onc is the Cyber director and he is a real top doc, Stanford grad, that I respect imensely.   I have three stubborn liver mets that I consulted with him on for Cyber.  The total volume has to be under 6cm.  The reason being, although the liver will regenerate itself, it will develop scar muscle when radiated.  It does not regenerate like most would think. I am a bigger fan of Cyroablation for the liver which is done by an interventional radiologist.  It is easy for them to see on CT the lesion and the formation of the ice ball to be sure they are getting only the lesions with minimal margins and there is emerging data suggesting that this particular method causes an immune reaction by the body not seen with RFA (heat or radio waves) or any radiation. Since your liver is vital and we especially tax it with chemo and will need to continue to have future chemos, I would leave any radiation to the liver as a last choice. If you go the Cyber route, I would only have it done at Stanford.  Just my humble opinions, here. Let us know how things go and good luck....Darlene

Posts.Content: Feb 25, 2010 08:02AM DARLENEDENISE wrote: Elizabeth:  Cyberknife veteran here.  I have had 11 critters zapped.  I have had to lay there perfectly still in one session for 3 freaking hours!  Be sure to go pee before you go in!  The mask is tightened to imbolize you and you will find it better to have eyes shut and no make up.  The mask leaves a lovely imprint on your forehead and cheeks.  You will not be camera ready when you leave!  When they do the CT simulation and make your mask, ask them to make the nose area a little loose.  They can pull on it before it hardens and it does make it easier to breathe and relax.  My first mask was too tight on the nose and it really bugged me. Put on lots of chap stick.  The room is dry and COLD and you wont be able to lick your lips or open your mouth to swallow. I have a two mask collection.  I put my wig, some glitter false eyelashes and wax lips on the first one.  I call her Hoochey Mamma.  Went with Mr Potato Head on the second one.  The posts on the back of the eyes and lips stick in the holes of the mask well.  Spudnick! Just wanted you to know that after 11 zaps, I still know my name and my ABC's!! Wishing you well and no extra critters on your MRI!!! Darlene

diagnosed at age 37 with extensive liver mets and did endure 9 months of chemo.  She had told her onc and family that she would endure no more treatments and went off the chemo at 9 months and our onc had to beg her to accept Herceptin (she was a lottery recipient of the drug in 1998).  When she stopped treatment he had been working behind the scenes to get her approved to receive the drug and it took him 3 months.  He told her you can chose to take it and you can chose to stop it if it impedes your QOL.  She agreed to try Herceptin and has only been on Herceptin with no real QOL issues, other than going in for infusions every three weeks since 1998 and is still NED, has worked, watched her 3 children graduate, go on to college and became a grandmother 10 months ago.  I am on Xeloda which is an oral chemo I take at home with a good QOL and have been on it since Jan.  This was not my oncologists first choice for me and he wanted to give me a more agressive cytotoxic chemo.  I know others who have been on Xeloda for several years and are stable.  Had they not tried Xeloda they would have subcumbed to the disease.  Months with a good QOL is a HUGE gift to you and your family.  I don't know you or what information you based your decision on, I can only hope you have been given all of the CORRECT medical information about YOUR type of breast cancer. You can even chose to skip standard of care regimens and perhaps try something aimed at QOL and see if it gives you comfortable time.  Even if you forgo chemo or target therapies,  there are palliative treatments that will improve your QOL during your remaining time.  Please don't close your mind to these options.  Your thoughts, feelings and need for support are always welcomed here.  There are many women here for you.  I sense you do not want the pity and attention this disease brings.  You don't have to tell anyone but who you chose to tell.  I did not want the pity part and I can say what I perceived as pity has shown to be true care and compassion and friendships at a depth I have never known and would have never known otherwise.  Another gift in this mess. I wish you peace and comfort physically and spiritually as you move forward. With loving respect, Darlene

Posts.Content: Mar 2, 2010 01:29PM DARLENEDENISE wrote: Tami:  Request a change of policy ownership making you the owner and keep your father as primary beneficiary, then make the claim.  Accelerated Death Benefits are a pre-payment of the policy face amount, they are not a loan and do not under any circumstances have to be re-paid.  Any assets can be used in determining eligibility for certain programs such as Medi-CAID and Social Security INCOME, programs for those with limited resources.  Not to be confused with Medi-CARE and Social Security DISABILITY which are not affected by assets and are granted to us because we have paid SS and Medicare taxes.  As metastatic breast cancer patients we automatically are granted SSD and will be eligible for Medicare health benefits after 29 months from SSD date of disability determination. Although you are NED and have had a nice long dance with it, your disease is UNPREDICTABLE and sadly for all of us, it can change in one scan.  Your onc will be attesting to "statistics", not  just your individual prediction, which he really does not know, no one does.  Your insurance company knows this too.  It is not likely they will request anything more than the claim form once they see that you have Metastatic Breast Cancer.  Even if they do, and find a way to not pay the claim, what have you lost?  You are not a cheater or making a fraudulent claim.  You are taking the steps set forth by the policy contract to see if you are eligible for a policy benefit that you have paid for. I think  your onc should and will simply sign off on the form.  They do these types of things every day.  You need to take these steps while you have a valid contract and are well enough to make these decisions.  I encourage you to obtain advice from a trusted adviser after obtaining the funds about using them to pay off your father's mortgage.  There may be reasons to not use the funds in that manner.  Might be better to use it to make payments and keep the bulk of the money available to help you in the future, should you need it for disability, medical reasons, etc.  Once it's gone, it's gone.   Just want you to consider YOUR best interests now and later. I hope this goes your way (I expect it will)!!  Let us know...Darlene

Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2010 01:04PM DARLENEDENISE wrote: Jen:  I took my benefits from all three of my life insurance policies.  One group and two individual.  I actually was the writing insurance agent for my two individual policies, that really makes it weird when you process your own claim forms!  Most policies are 12 months life expectancy, some six.  Insurance is based on statistics.  The insurance industry knows that no one doctor or you knows exactly will you will die.  If you have a disease that statistically meets their definition and you supply supporting documents, then you are entitled to the benefits contained in the policy contract.  If your doctor has signed off on the forms, he is not sure about your time, he is simply attesting to your dx and the stats the disease carries.  I'm sure he feels an obligation also to provide you with this document to enable you to obtain all of the support you need and are entitled to, not that he really thinks or knows your timeline.  While the benefits are in force and available to you, I say take your benefits and use them as it best benefits you and your family.  It's the least you should get in this deal. Posts.Content: Apr 21, 2010 09:28AM DARLENEDENISE wrote: Tami444:  Hooray!!  I'm so glad for you to have this piece of mind.  Just passing along some random thoughts.  I can't help it, I was an insurance agent/financial adviser.  It's not always in your best interest to pay mortgages etc off.  Remember, you will more than likely not be able to earn money in the future due to treatments/disability.  Don't let all you have go.  Any monies you choose to save, consider putting in only in your name with POD arrangements for your husband, family etc.  Although many of us have very supportive husbands, like this disease, things change and some leave or want to spend the money, so, protect yourselves.  If you have paid off loans, mortgages, etc that are in joint names, that money is gone if he should leave.  I have spoken with women whose husband also became disabled, lost a job, died etc and they found themselves in need of cash and these circumstances do not allow them to get credit any longer.  I recently looked into a procedure for my liver and if eligible, would have had to pay for my probes (not an FDA approved procedure yet, still in research) and travel to have it done.  Easily I would have needed $40,000.  Another reason to have some money aside.  I often see posts of women that can't get certain drugs approved by insurance.  I want all of my medical options available, even if I have to pay for some. Posts.Content: Mar 28, 2010 04:48AM - edited Mar 28, 2010 04:51AM by DARLENEDENISE The question will be, Have you been diagnosed, treated or displayed symptoms of cancer in the last (blank) years.  Usually 2-5 years.  Along with heart, AIDS etc.  They will also ask if you have been treated in an Er, hospital or doctors office for these or any other reasons not stated in (blank) number of years.  No medical exam, does not mean there will not be medical questions.  They will usually require your primary care doctors information to order reports.  If you do not list one, it will be a major underwriting red flag. NED doesn't mean you don't have cancer, that would be a cure.  NED means there is no CURRENT evidence of the disease detectable by current scans and testing, you still have cancer and it will be come evident again. Stage IV, even NED, will be a no go, I'm sorry to say.  Because of my life insurance background, I have had many pm's aimed at trying to "find ways around" this and I just want to stress, that the application becomes part of the policy contract and any misrepresentations or ommissions will cause the company to exercise the contestibility clause and not pay your beneficiaries the policy face amount, only a return of the premiums that you paid. And in this economy, you better believe they will investigate heavily any short term death. If you have a large sum of money, there are some companies that will accept it and set a live to date and if you live past it your family will get the stated death benefit.  For example if you have $25K and the insurance company accepts it and you live say, 10 years, a death benefit of $50k would be paid.  This is not a market I worked in and don't know much more about it that this.  But maybe a life representative with a large life insurance only company would be able to help you. Sorry to spread such unwelcome information.  Darlene

Posts.Content: May 23, 2010 09:37PM DARLENEDENISE wrote: Accelerated benefits can be on term, universal life, group life and whole life contracts.  If it is not on your policy based on it not being offered at the time you purchased it and you did not initially refuse the coverage if it was available and the company now offers it on similar contracts, it can be added and then a claim made.  It is an endorsement that is usually added or included for no additional premium.  If you are able to claim accelerated benefits the balance of coverage will be reissued and you will be able convert the term coverage to a whole life or universal life product that will enable you to continue coverage beyond 2014, regardless of your health.  Be sure to leave enough coverage in place to qualify for a conversion.  I would consider keeping the balance on the term policy and look at conversion closer to the end of the term.  Even if your policy doesn't have accelerated benefits and it can't be added, you can still convert all or part of the term.   Request assistance and guidance from your agent or directly from the life servicing division of the company that issued the policy.  You may find that dealing directly with the company a better situation, many agents have not had experience with this policy provision and I have seen many give incorrect info.  Also check to see if your policy has premium disability waiver that would waive future premiums. Good luck on this....Darlene

Can you go for another opinion with a NCI facility, if you are not sure that your onc is heading in the right direction or just to put your mind at ease about your choices?  I went to Dana Farber just to explore all of my options and gain knowledge to work more effectively with my local onc.  My onc is brilliant, but I needed to cast my research net to get me through my brain mets.  I figure it's always better to cast a large net than fish with a small pole!!  This damn disease will rob you of all that you are, if you let it, don't let it!!  I dig into research info so I can make a plan and have intelligent conversation with my onc.  It empowers me and keeps me busy.  It also enables me to help others.  DIG IN!!  Stay on the highway, come up with a new plan that may very well kick your cancer's ass, and put you in the fast lane!!  I'll be watching and waiting for you drive by with with a big net full of options and good news to share with all of us soon!  Your friend in Virginia Beach...Darlene PS  You haven't failed anything, the drugs failed you!!  By the way, I have driven past liver mets and am currently doing a drive by shooting of my brain mets!!  Cancer better stay the hell out of my lane!

Posts.Content: Apr 10, 2010 05:41PM DARLENEDENISE wrote: Dang, Dasiylego:  Sorry for the overwhelming fear you are experiencing.  I had a melt down myself.  Laid on the kitchen floor and would only let my son lay with me, for hours!  Many of us have had them and  for many more than once.  It's okay.  It upsets those that love us to see it, but, they will get over it. Sorry about the liver spots.  I was one of the rare birds that was Stage IV with liver mets revealed during my routine scans that were done right after my breast biopsy.  Like you I was ready to deal with what I had been told, "I think we caught it early, Stage II."  I had no reason to even think otherwise, I had regular mammograms, every 6 months at times and all diagnostic ones.  I had no symptoms except some fatigue.   So, I thought for sure it would be a very early case.  My tumor markers were high, so my oncologist was pretty sure we were dealing with distant spread, but explained that he had to have confirmation by a biopsy.  It is an out patient procedure, not fun, but you will get through it.  I will hold out hope that these are NOT mets.  They can be other things as I am sure you were told about.  This is a good time for Xanax.  If you don't have any, call your doctor and ask that they call you in a few to help carry you through this anxious and difficult week.  I tried hard to be strong and not need any anti-anxiety drugs, it was much better for everyone that I took them when necessary, it really was a big help. I will be wishing, hoping and praying that you stay out of our club and that those spots are just spots!  Let us know if you need us and I for one will be looking to hear back about your test results.  Send us good news!! Darlene

Posts.Content: May 27, 2010 10:15AM DARLENEDENISE wrote: Vicki: No, they cannot drop you for any reason other than not paying the premiums.  I don't want to come of as insensitive, but, this is not an emotional issue for your doctors as it is to you.  This is a business/insurance transaction and you are not the first patient to request this from your oncologist.  They deal with it all of the time.  Handle it like business.  It is a contractual benefit that you are entitled to.  You don't need to speak to your onc about this.  If it is an emotional  difficulty for you then just ask your onc's office who handles life insurance paperwork for your onc and give it to them.  Tell them you want to pick it up when it is completed and ask that they NOT send it in to the insurance company.  Attach a note to remind them.  When it is completed, check to see it is answered in your favor to obtain the benefit.  If not, THEN speak to your onc and see what can be done.  Be sure to make a copy of the incomplete form so it can be re-done if need be.  Corrected forms are a red flag, so, be sure the form is clean. Many gals who have obtained their benefits would say all of the worry and anxiety was for naught.  You and your family deserve this valuable benefit.

Posts.Content: Apr 11, 2010 09:11AM DARLENEDENISE wrote: Daisylego:  Tumor markers are not considered part of routine CBC or CMPs.  My liver and all of my other blood tests were in the normal range too at diagnosis.  CA27-29 is the test utilized to see about your tumor markers.  It is a different blood test and is not routinely run.  Some oncs don't use them, mine does and he orders them every three weeks to see if treatment is working.  He uses that info combined with how I feel and scans to get a real picture.  Mine were elevated.  Normal is 30 and at diagnosis they were 93.  Markers are not always reliable for each person.  Your doctor, if he uses them, will have to watch yours a while to see how they trend. Ask your onc if he/she will be ordering these markers and if they use them in the course of your treatments.  I hope this helps.  I like to know what mine are, some gals prefer not to know.  Try not to worry about anything you do not know to be factual.  Educate yourself to a level that makes you comfortable.  Many smart cookies on this site.  Call out to them if you have questions. Darlene

Posts.Content: Jul 31, 2010 05:00PM DARLENEDENISE wrote: Hi:  Sorry your mom is dealing with all of this too.  I did not have WBR, only Cyberknife.  Eight lesions treated 09/08 and three popped up in 06/09.  The first eight have completely resolved and no longer visible on scan.  Just had a scan 07/19/10 and the last three still appear but after 13 months of no change, considered necrotic.  Rad report says, stable. Posts.Content: Sep 12, 2010 03:02AM DARLENEDENISE wrote: I say clear the stage and get a new group of players.  Ones who deal with metastatic breast cancer a lot and only are breast oncologists.  At this point the surgeon is no longer the driver of the bus.  Since it has spread, a oncologist specializing in breast cancer with a large mets patient population is the new driver and will call the shots.  You may need a surgeon again, jut not now and not guiding any of your care.  If the facility you are at is not a NCI accredited facility, I urge to to develop a relationship with one ASAP.  You can get your continued care at your local cancer center and coordinate all decisions with the doctor at the NCI facility.  At these institutions they see women like us every day, are not afraid of giving us care and have the latest research info to guide them.  This is advanced cancer and requires ADVANCED care.  It won't come to you, you have to go get it.  I get consultive care and trial info at Dana Farber in Boston, local care in Virginia Beach with an onc who did residency at Sloan Kettering and has many contacts there, brain treatment at UNC Chappel Hill in NC where my nuerosurgeon is widely published and well known the brain surgery world and recently EAP study at Sarah Cannon Cancer Research Center in Nashville.  I don't like to travel, but I will not accept shitty standard of care and doctors who don't push the medical envelope in my behalf.  I have been dealing with liver mets since 12/07 at my inital dx and brain mets since 09/08.  I hope all of the words from this forum will empower you to move past this inital fear and begin to find your best way to outstanding care.  If you share where you live, I'd be happy to tell you of nearby facilities that you might want to consider. It is hard to follow through on this when you are so scared.  I'm just one mean witch when it comes to my health so nothing scares me.  If you need help, find your strongest ally and ask them to help you advocate and help you with information. Really, I'm not bossy, I just hate cancer and seeing someone in a situation that is not the their best interests. Stay strong....Darlene
Posts.Title: Sorry to be joining you and I'm scared to death... bopeep leprechaun

Posts.Content: Aug 18, 2009 09:28PM DARLENEDENISE wrote: I say, yes you are.  Are you having some type of reaction or unmanagable side effects?  My friend who was 36 at dx has been on it without additional chemo since 1997 and is just now having issues with a low muga score.  I know many other women on the other bc boards who have been on it over 10 years.  Since you are young, you will probably tolerate it well for a long time. You are indeed in an enviable mets position and may get to ride with Herceptin mono-therapy for a long time.  This is not a be done with it type disease, which is why they call it incurable.  You will need to manage your cancer, always.  My initial dx was mets to the liver and even though I did Taxol, Carbo, Herceptin for 13 weeks and got the all clear on my liver, then had lumpectomy and axillary node dissection (path showed clean margins and no nodes) and had 35 rad sessions, then continued with mono-therapy Herceptin, 8 months later it made it's way to my brain.  Even though your scans may show "no evidence of disease"  now, you still have circulating cancer cells that have "metastasized" to distant sites that are microscopic and cannot be seen on scans and  they will eventually grow.  The name of the game is to slow that progression which requires treatment.  No treatment will equal progression.  Then you will need nasty chemo again with Herceptin.  I would do anything to increase my odds to not have chemo again anytime soon. An IV treatment every three weeks is a small price to pay.  This is a sneaky, evil disease that lurks in our bodies, never let your guard down.  My onc has many patients out over 5 years because of the continuance of Herceptin and gives it for life.  Good luck...Darlene

Posts.Content: Jun 19, 2010 10:53PM DARLENEDENISE wrote: I vote to keep it at current dose.  I did TCH and was supposed to have it for 15 treatments.  My chemo nurse miscounted and on the 13th dose advised the PA that I had had all 15 and they changed me to Herceptin.  I kept telling the nurse that she was wrong.  Anyway, I reviewed my info at home and confirmed only 13.  Spoke to PA and she said "well, you are really over getting chemo and the last two doses were for good measure anyway, so it's up to you if you want the last two."  My recent scans showed only two immeasurable lesions left in the liver so she felt Herceptin would take care of them.  Nope!  They stayed stable until my next scan 4 months later and the next scan at 8 months they had progressed.  That was Jan 09 and I have been on three failed chemos and now am on Navelbine that appears to be working, but they had grown considerably and have proven to be very stubborn.  From my experience, I say complete the chemo until they are GONE before switching to Herceptin.  I had some neuropothay as well and it cleared up within six months.  I have some occasional tinglling but have full use of my apendages.  Let everyone else change those diapers!!!!  You have a real deal excuse!!!!  LOL Hope everything works out for you.  Sending my best. Stay strong...Darlene

Posts.Content: Jul 1, 2009 11:16PM DARLENEDENISE wrote: I had innumerable liver lesions and I had pronounced pain that required use of Percocet.  Lesions on the liver will cause pain by expanding the capsule of the liver due to lesion growth AND pain when they are SHRINKING.  When mine were growing it was an on and off pain under the edge of my right rib that was dull to moderate and came and went.  When they were shrinking it hurt MORE.  The pain was much more intense and lasted longer and I had to take Percocet.  I did not believe my doctor when he told me it could be from shrinkage, but my first scan showed dramatic reduction, he was right. How are they sure they are mets, biopsy, PET scan? I hope this is helpful/hopeful info and that mom's lesions are shrinking!

Posts.Content: Aug 2, 2010 08:31PM DARLENEDENISE wrote: Joyce:  I would never leave Herceptin, except for TDM1.  I have been on Xeloda, Tykerb & Herceptin together but was unable to stay on it due to liver progression and side effects.  Since she has already had WBR treatment and they are better, that seems like good news!  She may or may not have been a candidate for SRS.  Since she has been treated already, you can only go forward from here.  To try to keep the brain stable, I would want to add Tykerb to the Herceptin.  If she develops progression in the body, I would want to think about adding in Xeloda.  The side effects of the three can be harsh for some, so, I would see what the addition of Tykerb could do first.  Some oncs will not want to give the Tykerb unless there is some measurable disease to be sure it is working.  It is almost impossible to determine the effect in the brain. It took a long time for the first eight lesions to totally dissolve and not be visible on scans.  Even after 13 months the last 3 treated are still the same size, but since no increase in 13 months they are considered necrotic and may or may not dissolve completely.  It may take a while before you see reduction in size.  WBR delivers grays of radiation in lower amounts over a period of time and it is not uncommon for it to take some time. I hope you are able to arrange the addition of the Tykerb without too much resistance, if you decide to use it. Darlene

Posts.Content: Aug 2, 2010 04:44PM DARLENEDENISE wrote: Hi Joyce and all the other sweet ladies on our forum!  I recall that your daughter just recently completed WBR.  Are these new lesions that are mentioned here?  This is an area of medicine that is not evidence based, therefore, you will find varying individual medical opinions.  You will find that the options presented sometimes reflect the type of radiation equipment the doctor you are consulting with has at his disposal. Treatment of brain mets outside of standard of care WBR requires seeking out equipment, open minded physicians and the right facility.  Typically, you will do better at a university NCI facility that has a tumor board.  It is very important to know that the number of lesions is not the key to being a candidate for SRS.  Tumor volume, where they are located and your level of education play the largest role in determining if SRS could be utilized in your INDIVIDUAL case.  Don't go by my treatment or anyone else's.  All of the factors about your case have to be considered.  DO reach out for all available options and considerations BEFORE accepting WBR or any proposed treatments. Chain and I are happy to know that we offer encouragement to those who are afraid to look at ALL options.  Please call out to us anytime.  Love you Chain!!! Stay Strong....Darlene

Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2010 04:26PM DARLENEDENISE wrote: Liz:  Your policy may have the endorsement for you to review.  Keep in mind, it may not be on the policy, but you can have it added at no charge and then make the claim.  I don't understand why you are afraid to ask.  It won't change the terms of the policy contract if you inquire.  You should be able to obtain benefits on both of the policies.   Ask also if you have waiver of premium on the individual policy.  The group policy should have a disability provision that will waive future premiums after a stated period of time.  Your premiums on the individual will be reduced based on the reduced policy amount.  Example:  Policy is $100,0000 and premium is $50 per month.  You take accelerated death benefits of 50% which is $50,0000.  Your policy death benefit will reduce to $50,000, a new policy face sheet will be issued for the balance of $50,0000 and premium of $25 would be charged. I was a Life and Property/Casualty agent for many years.  If you have any questions as you work through this, feel free to ask me. Darlene
